title: Getting duplicate deprecations (which makes the count wrong)
body:
Working on upgrading a project I got this output to stdout:

```
6 deprecations logged to ./log/rspec-deprecations.log
```

But when I go look at that file, here's what I see:

```
`be_true` is deprecated. Use `be_truthy` (for Ruby's conditional semantics) or `be true` (for exact `== true` equality) instead. Called from /Users/myron/moz/vanguard/spec/acceptance/shard_creation_spec.rb:313:in `verify_completed_jobs'.
```

136 lines of the same deprecation.  My initial thought was that there were 130 lines from the prior test run (even though it should overwrite the file each test run), so I deleted it an ran again.  Same deal.  (Actually, on the first time it had ~ 205 lines of the same deprecation. The 136 lines above was from the second time).

There are a few problems here:
- The `6 deprecations logged to ./log/rspec-deprecations.log` message is totally wrong compared to what printed.  Actually, looking at my code -- I think that particular call site was encountered 6 times during the run, so that's my guess of where 6 times came from.
- Given it was the same call site each time, the deprecation message was identical.  I don't think there's any reason to ever print the same identical deprecation message more than once, no matter how many times it's call site is executed.
- There's some really odd bug causing _a lot_ of extra duplicates to show up in the deprecation output file.  No idea why.

/cc @soulcutter
